description:
Participate in an exclusive Big Data Developer Day hosted by the IBM Big Data Technical Sales team. Experience IBM’s enterprise-class big data platform that allows you to address the full spectrum of big data business challenges. The morning will include interactive discussions and live demonstrations of big data for social media and real-time analytics, then get hands-on with text analytics, stream computing, and app development with guidance from development experts. This is a unique opportunity to develop skills and learn about exciting technologies and techniques that you can immediately take back to your organization.

•Big Data at Rest (IBM® InfoSphere® BigInsights™)
•Big Data in Motion (IBM® InfoSphere® Streams)

__________

 

AGENDA:

8:00 AM - 9:00 AM Breakfast & Registration

9:00 AM - 10:00 AM Overview of the IBM Big Data Platform

10:00 AM - 10:30 AM Interactive discussions & live demonstrations: Social Media

10:30 AM - 11:00 AM Break

11:00 AM - 11:30 AM Interactive discussions & live demonstrations: Machine Data Analytics Demo


11:30 PM - 12:00 PM Interactive discussions & live demonstrations: Real Time Analytics Demo

12:00 PM - 1:00 PM Lunch

1:00 PM - 6:00 PM Hands-On Lab with Hadoop Text Analytics/Hadoop
Scripting, JAQL, Spreadsheet analytics for Big Data, SPL ProgrammingScripting and text analytics.

*Note - Please bring your laptop if you plan to participate in the hands on lab

name: Participate in an exclusive Big Data Developer Day hosted by IBM.

description:
Discussion/presentation of Hive and BigSQL.

Big SQL doesn't turn Hadoop into one big distributed relational database. If you're curious about what Big SQL can do, we'll explore the basics here, try to clear up some common misconceptions, and answer many of the questions that relational DBMS users often have about this new technology.

We'll also discuss Hive - the "SQL-like" capability that is part of Hadoop.
name: Topic: SQL Access to HDFS Data

description:
The IBM Big Data Platform provides secure federated navigation and discovery across a broad range of enterprise content and big data to maximize return on information.

By delivering information to the right people at the right time, organizations gain the full value of their data, enabling improved operations, real-time decisions, better understanding of customers, increased innovation and actionable insight.

We will look at the "Visualization and Discovery" aspect of the IBM Big Data Platform available through Infosphere Data Explorer.

For a quick business overview, please review this video (< 10 minutes). We will cover the technology in more detail at the Meetup.

 

Map to IBM office
how_to_find_us: Corner of Central Ave and Thomas Road. You may use the parking garage on Catalina ($).
name: Big Data Platform - Visualization and Discovery

description:
Streaming data is all around us – from social media feeds to call data records – but can be difficult to leverage. Sometimes there is simply too much data to collect and store before analyzing it. Sometimes it’s an issue of timing – by the time they store data on disk, analyze it, and respond – it’s too late. Organizations need a way to harness the natural resource of streaming data and turn it into actionable insight. Enter stream computing.


Stream computing changes where, when and how much of your business data you can analyze. By extracting insight from data as it is streaming, you can react to events as they are happening to reshape business outcomes. Store less, analyze more, and make better decisions, faster. From increased customer retention to earlier fraud detection to more frequent cross-selling, the benefits of stream computing are many. 

______________________

Here is a map <a href="http://photos3.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/3/8/3/8/global_274034392.jpeg"></a>to the meeting location.


Enter the building from the ground floor lobby and use the south elevator bank to go to the 5th floor.

Please note - the doors close at 6:00 pm. Plan to arrive early enough to be in the room by 5:45 - for networking and pizza. You may come as early as 5:00.
name: Stream Computing - Real-time analytics processing for actionable insight

description:
IBM is pleased to announce a Proof of Technology event for IBM BigInsights (an Enterprise Hadoop solution) to analyze BigData to be held on Tuesday Oct 22, 2013, in the IBM Phoenix office.

For those unfamiliar with IBM's Proof of Technology sessions, they are a combination of lecture and hands-on labs in order give attendees hands-on experience with the products. This BigInsights PoT will be unique in that all attendees will be given a copy of the free distribution version of BigInsights. Meetup Group Attendees must bring their own personal laptops to load the distribution and use their own laptop for class labs.

About BigInsights:
IBM® Big Data addresses key customer enterprise data requirements and provides a robust platform for the three V's: Variety, Velocity and Volume. Built on a foundation of open source components, IBM extends the platform to provide additional analytics, enhanced ease of use, and extensive integration to provide an enterprise class solution. In this Proof of Technology, we will explore data at rest using IBM InfoSphere Big Insights. This session consists of both presentation and hands-on lab exercises.

Objective:
IT professionals can gain experience with Big Data and IBM's offerings in this fast moving area of computing..

Audience:
This Proof of Technology is for Data analysts, Data Management Architects, Database Developers and other decision influencers who are evaluating IBM technologies

• Lab Exercise 3: Querying social media and structured data: An introduction to Jaql
• Lab Exercise 4: Text Analytics for Social Media Data: An introduction to AQL
• Lab Exercise 5: Developing, publishing, and deploying your first Big Data application with InfoSphere BigInsights

description:
THIS IS A WEB CONFERENCE ONLY - TIME INDICATED IS LOCAL START TIME. SEE BELOW FOR DETAILS.

IBM InfoSphere Streams V3.2 (referred to as Streams) delivers a highly scalable, agile software infrastructure to perform in-motion analytics on a wide variety of relational and non-relational data types that enter the enterprise at unprecedented volumes and speed, and from thousands of real-time sources. Streams V3.2 includes new features and functions designed to instantly analyze and fuse massive volumes of data and integrates with existing infrastructures. It delivers new capabilities to improve usability, support enterprise readiness, and streamline enterprise integration.

WHAT:

The following new features and functions, which will be covered during the Streams Developer Conference:

Usability:
• Remote Development with Streams Studio for Windows and Linux
• User Defined Parallelism
• Java Streams development simplification

Enterprise readiness:
• Operational Decision Management adapter for business rules
• Access to application data using Representational State Transfer (REST)

Enterprise integration:
• MQTT adapters
• Hadoop Big SQL support
• HP Vertica Analytic Database support

Who should attend:

The event assumes you are familiar with Streams. If you are not, please either try the Big Data University Streams course or review some of the Streams videos on YouTube.

Webcast on Thursday November 14, 2013 from 10:00AM to 6:00PM U.S. Eastern Standard Time.

description:
Big Data Meetup: Hands-on with Text Analytics -  Extracting business value from Text

Join us on Wednesday, November 20 at 6:00pm in Phoenix.  This Meetup will be a presentation, demo and hands-on lab.  

As enterprises seek to gain operational efficiencies and competitive advantage through greater use of analytics, much of the new information they need to analyze is found in text documents and, increasingly, in a wide variety of social media sites and portals. A critical step in gaining insights from this information is extracting core data from huge volumes of text. That data is then available for downstream analytic, mining and machine learning tools. AQL (Annotator Query Language) is a powerful declarative, rule-based language for the extraction of information from text documents.

This Meetup is FREE.  Food and beverages will be provided. Please bring your laptop to participate in the hands-on lab.   Download BigInsights Quick Start Edition (single-node) before the event: http://ibm.co/QuickStart

name: Big Data Developer's Day Hosted by IBM

description:
Join IBM Subject Matter Experts as they discuss how machine data analysis can prevent outages, as well as provide insights for business imperatives such as fraud detection, customer retention, and other important use cases.

Machines produce huge amounts of data that contain valuable and actionable information. However, accessing and working with that information requires large-scale import, extraction, transformation, and statistical analysis. IBM® Accelerator for Machine Data Analytics, a set of end-to-end applications, helps you import, extract, index, transform, and analyze your data to perform faceted search and event and pattern correlation and then make informed decisions based on the intelligence contained in log and data files.
With IBM Accelerator for Machine Data Analytics, you can:

  -Search within and across multiple log entries based on a text search, faceted search, or a timeline-based search to find events
  -Enrich the context of log data by adding and extracting log types into the existing repository
  -Link and correlate events across systems
  -Uncover patterns
name: Machine Data Analysis- A Big Data Business Imperative!

description:
In last month's discussion, we discussed STREAMS and the use of Annotator Query Language (AQL) and other tools to analyze real time data.

Come learn how to boost your Text Analytics productivity and capabilities with AQL!! 

This session we will discussAQL, a query language designed for Text Analytics which provides analysts and programmers a set of SQL-like expressions so it’s immediately familiar, making it easier to learn and develop. The engine was developed by IBM research. IBM has been working in this area for many years and regularly work with customers to extend and enhance its capabilities.

Why and What is Text Analytics?

Text Analytics is a way to extract information from unstructured and semi-structured documents. By extracting information from these documents, you can combine it with other more traditional structured information to get a more complete view of your business, your customers and your competitors. Most text documents are written by people to convey information to other people so they don't follow strict rules controlling content, layout and style. As a result, you can't use traditional ETL tools to extract information from them. Call center records are a good example. They often include fields containing the text of a dialog with a customer and notes and comments made by the call center rep. There's lots of valuable information in these fields, but you can't extract it using ETL tools. The same is true for social media and sentiment data. These new data sources contain huge amounts of very valuable information about your business, your customers and your competitors, but if you want to extract meaningful information from data from blogs, tweets, call center records and other unstructured documents you need Text Analytics.

Using Text Analytics we can make it easier to intelligently search and access information from these documents and we can open up the information to traditional Business Intelligence and warehousing tools and technologies. Machines are very good at quickly applying unambiguous rules that can be precisely encoded; but processing documents using rule based or grammar based extraction techniques doesn’t work very well; there's just too much variability and these systems usually become ‘brittle’. IBM Text Analytics is based on a system that lets you identify elements of interest and their context without writing complex and fragile grammars and rules. Think of the way you scan a document, identifying information of interest, determining the context and then extracting the information you need. IBM Text Analytics uses a similar machine based model.
name: AQL - Annotator Query Language

description:
Are you a born-on-the-web and mobile developer, or startup/entrepreneur, or an independent software vendor looking to make services available in the cloud? Maybe you need to iterate on something quickly. Maybe you want to experiment with different technologies. Maybe you just want to build, extend, and deploy with the efficiency of a cold-blooded cyborg. Whatever you want to do, BlueMix offers a single solution environment that lets you develop, deploy and manage apps of all types (web, mobile, big data, new smart devices) across multiple domains.  If the answer is yes to any of these questions, you don't want to miss this meetup session. You will learn how to to deploy your application and have it running in a matter of hours.


http://youtu.be/VOqmR2nSCHY


http://youtu.be/ZR_jDitw0Sc


BlueMix is an implementation of IBM’s Open Cloud Architecture, leveraging Cloud Foundry to enable developers to rapidly build, deploy, and manage their cloud applications, while tapping a growing ecosystem of available services and runtime frameworks. Capabilities include Java, mobile backend development, application monitoring, Hadoop, as well as capabilities from ecosystem partners and open source — all through an as-a-service model in the cloud. 

Attend this event to help you get started with Open Cloud and where developers can act like kids in a sandbox - except this box is enterprise-grade.

Learn more about BlueMix: https://ace.ng.bluemix.net/

name: Getting started with Open Cloud for mobile as-a-service & Big Data applications

description:
Streaming data originates from a myriad of sources both internal and external to the enterprise. From such diverse sources as social media feeds, Call Detail Records (CDRs), consumer transactions, financial markets, machine sensors, etc., streaming data is present in virtually every modern business process and social interaction. However, the sheer speed and volume of this data type makes it difficult to leverage using conventional systems.

Typically, there is too much data to collect, store, and analyze in a timely fashion. By the time data is stored on disk and analyzed, the response is no longer relevant. Organizations need a system that captures the value of streaming data in near-real-time and transforms it into actionable insight. – Enter IBM InfoSphere® Streams.

Streams processing is a new computing model that affects the “when,” “where,” and “how” of enterprise data analysis. By processing data as soon as it is captured, the enterprise can react rapidly to events as they occur, resulting in optimized business outcomes. From increased customer retention; to earlier fraud detection; to more productive cross-selling, the benefits of streams processing are many. IBM InfoSphere Streams uses innovative technology to perform rapid real-time analysis of information originating from a myriad of disparate sources resulting in positive outcomes for the enterprise. This Meet-Up session introduces participants to the capabilities of the IBM InfoSphere® Streams platform. The objective of this session is to demonstrate, via simple use cases, the features of the InfoSphere Streams platform. We also present the IBM InfoSphere® Streams Integrated Development Environment (IDE) and deployment tools.
name: Don't LAND it!  LEARN from it!  STREAMING ANALYTICS!!

description:
!! Registration Required Before May 30, 2014 (see below), Limited Seating, auto Wait-listing!!

To register for this event, go to the IBM Internet of Things / NoSQL Events page at: http://tinyurl.com/m6zw5sd


Please join us for a FREE one-day technical event designed to give you hands-on
experience with IBM’s solution for Internet of Things / NoSQL environments,
whether deployed in a public or private cloud or hosted in the data center.

A massive change is occurring in computing environments around the world.
Unstructured data is flooding into organizations and companies are struggling to
choose between a relational or NoSQL database to handle it. While NoSQL offers
dynamic elasticity with data and its organization, these databases lack essential
elements common to enterprise class databases. Today, IBM offers a solution that can natively handle NoSQL and structured data simultaneously giving you the flexibility and development speed of NoSQL with all the features and
characteristics of an enterprise class database.

This roadshow will help you understand how application developers can use full
NoSQL functionality (including sharding) for complete plug-and-play compatibility with MongoDB and graph-store databases. They can access structured and unstructured data in a single statement and join them together as needed. These applications can use the enterprise-level capabilities of a structured database system including transaction support, backup and recovery, H/A, compression, enhanced scalability, security and access control. IBM's solution also enables the execution of comprehensive analytics using Cognos or other BI tools on NoSQL data in IBM's market-leading in-memory data warehouse acceleration technology, commonly referred to as BLU.

To register for the event, go to the IBM Internet of Things / NoSQL Events page at: http://tinyurl.com/m6zw5sd
how_to_find_us: Park in garage @ 3rd Street & Catalina (fee required)
name: Developer's Workshop: NoSQL functionality (including sharding)

description:
Come and join use fo the look into BigSQL 3.0!  Come for networking and Food at 6:30 PM and we'll get started at 7:00 PM.  We look forward to seeing you there!


When considering SQL-on-Hadoop, the most fundamental question is: What is the right tool for the job? For interactive queries that require a few seconds (or even milliseconds) of response time, MapReduce (MR) is the wrong choice. On the other hand, for queries that require massive scale and runtime fault tolerance, an MR framework works well. MR was built for large-scale processing on big data, viewed mostly as “batch” processing.


As enterprises start using Apache Hadoop as a central data repository for all data — originating from sources as varied as operational systems, sensors, smart devices, metadata and internal applications — SQL processing becomes an optimal choice. A fundamental reason is that most enterprise data management and analytical tools rely on SQL.


As a tool for interactive query execution, SQL processing (of relational data) benefits from decades of research, usage experience and optimizations. Clearly, the SQL skills pool far exceeds that of MR developers and data scientists. As a general-purpose processing framework, MR may still be appropriate for ad hoc analytics, but that is as far as it can go with current technology.
name: Leverage what you already know with - SQL on Hadoop

description:
Data Management in the Big Mobile and Internet of Things Era – NoSQL Database as a Service with Cloudant, an IBM company 

Today’s applications are expected to manage a variety of structured and unstructured data, accessed by massive networks of users, devices, and business locations, or even sensors, vehicles and Internet-enabled goods.

The Cloudant database as a service (DBaaS) is the first data management platform to leverage the availability, elasticity, and reach of the cloud to create a global data delivery network (DDN) that enables applications to scale globally and remain available to users wherever they are.

Cloudant is built from the ground up to scale globally (think CDN for your database), run non-stop, and handle a wide variety of indexing technologies including map-reduce, full-text search, and geo spatial. Cloudant is an operational data store optimized to handle concurrent reads & writes, and provide high availability and data durability.

Cloudant is used by Samsung, Adobe, Microsoft, Fidelity Investments, Hothead Games, and thousands of others who share Cloudant’s passion for database scalability and innovation. Cloudant provides them with:

Massive Read/Write Scalability
Non-Stop Data Availability
Faster Development
Escape from Cloud Lock-In
name: NOSQL Database as a Service - Scalability & Innovation

description:
R is a powerful Open Source programming language and software environment that enables deep statistical analysis of data, and graphical representation of the results.  Key features include data exploration, statistical analysis, modeling, machine learning, simulations, and visualization of the results.

But, R's full potential is limited by process memory utilization and its inability to take advantage of parallel platforms, such as HADOOP, diminishing its ability to analyze very large data sets.  IBM's Big-R offering extends IBM’s Big Data & Analytics tool-set with a highly-scalable & massively parallel execution of R on HADOOP. These capabilities enable data scientists to focus on the statistical analysis of large data sets, without being concerned with the underlying infrastructure.

This session will provide an overview of R, a description of IBM's Big-R, and a DEMO of the capabilities of Big-R.


Pizza, Salad, Networking: 6:30-7:00
Meeting Start: 7:00
name: A Detailed Look at Big R: R + IBM InfoSphere BigInsights (Hadoop)

description:
CALLING ALL DEVELOPERS .... JOIN THE BIG DATA FOR SOCIAL GOOD CHALLENGE

Big data exists in just about everything we use and do. It comes from phones, cars, roads, power lines, waterways, food crates, and innumerable other items you’d never think of as computers. This data speaks volumes about our collective behavior and society – so let’s use it to do something incredible! IBM invites developers and data enthusiasts to take a deep dive into real world civic issues using big data and the IBM Bluemix Analytics for Hadoop service. Analyze one of our curated datasets or bring your own (provided it meets these requirements)! Use Hadoop and your data to create a clickable and interactive data visualization to highlight insights that you’ve found.

Ready to get started? $40,000 in prizes will be awarded....

Register here:http://ibmhadoop.challengepost.com/

What to Create: Participants must create a working, clickable, and interactive data visualization utilizing the Analytics for Hadoop service on IBM Bluemix.

Data Requirements: Your data visualization must analyze one or more datasets included in the curated list of datasets on the Data page OR meet the data size, content, and licensing requirements described on the Data page. The total size of the Datasets analyzed must be between 500MB - 7GB in size.

Check out the requirements then go get your IBM Bluemix extended promo code and check out the datasets!
name: Big Data for Social Good Challenge
venue_name: Big Data for Social Good Challenge

description:
Including; Hackathon Announcement: IBM's Big Data for Social Good Challenge


The ability to use data from public domain sources has been an exciting prospect for BI and Web Developers both in the commercial and public sector space. Of late, an increasing number of Hackathons and "Challenges" have been presented both by Academic and Commercial entities where the collaboration of designers, developers, testers, and users can come together to help learn as well as provide solutions.
Our meetup this month will feature a few developers who have used open data sources to provide their examples (we are still open to any others who would like to present)! Finally, IBM will discuss their "Big Data for Social Good Challenge". The challenge offers prizes for developers ranging from $1,000 through $20,000 in cash, along with the opportunity to earn a donation in your name to Plantabilion.org (Nature Conservancy).
Presenters (Subject to Change):
Dan Zubey - Solomon Communications Systems - A public safety communications engineer, Dan has created a notification and mapping system based off of publicly-available Phoenix Fire Department data, that geolocates fire calls, maps them, and creates notification events in the background.
Greg Morgan - Maricopa County - Greg has a lot of experience working with OpenStreetMap and other public data sources to present and analyze data. He will talk about a few of the projects he's worked on in his spare time (outside working hours).
Joe Junker - IBM - Joe will give us an overview of the Big Data for Social Good Challenge & a few of the tools IBM is allowing free access for developers to compete for these prizes
name: Open Data, Hackathons & Challenge Announcement

description:
The bigger your data, the bigger the problem if it is somehow lost. Hadoop, by default, helps with data redundancy/HA. In this presentation, Rakesh, as an expert in IBM BigInsights (IBM's Hadoop Distribution), will provide a perspective on the importance of understanding where open source and IBM tools/features store their data in the cluster, what are the prominent big data solutions for backup and DR, the major components in BigInsights that need to be backed up and why, and some specifics on implementing backup/DR solutions within BigInsights.

About the Presenter: Rakish Naik is currently a Big Data Technical Solution Specialist with IBM Americas. Rakesh has worked more than 20 years in IT in various roles, including a 4gl/C/Web developer, Informix DBA, System Admin, Advanced Support Engineer (Informix/DB2), and Technical Account Manager (Informix/DB2/Netezza). More recently, Rakesh worked as a Partner Enablement Specialist, where I developed and delivered Big Data (BigInsights/Streams/Watson Explorer/IPDA) bootcamps to IBM partners around the world, including assistance with system review, porting, and implementation activities.
Social / Networking: 6:30-7:10pm
Presentation: 7:10pm - 8:30pm
name: Backup and Disaster Recovery in Hadoop

description:
Registration required!
Use this Link:
https://docs.google.com/forms/d/13tpiXrNOTSM5APAgOeu_g2A7V3Bx3MxK598hUtkSIxk/viewform

Do your software projects stumble over the deployment hurdle? If so, you are not alone. Many software projects
struggle to achieve consistent deployments across their environments—from Test to UAT to Staging to
Production. Successful deployments must account for differences between environments; coordinate
development teams and environment owners; balance schedule pressures; and create the requisite audit trail.
When these challenges are compounded by error prone, inconsistent and inefficient manual processes, achieving
a consistent deployment can seem impossible.

At this event we will cover:
* the pitfalls of manual deployments;
* cultural barriers to improving deployment processes; and
* best practices, such as self-service deployments, and
* how IBM Software Group implemented DevOps practices!
RSVP / Registration Required!
name: DevOps with IBM UrbanCode & Application Deployment Automation

description:
6:30 - Networking & Pizza/Salads


7:00 - Presentation


In February 2015, industry leaders in the big data space, including GE, Hortonworks, IBM, Infosys, Pivotal, SAS, and others, announced their intent to create an industry association, identified as the Open Data Platform (“ODP”). The objective of this association was to promote open source-based big data technologies, optimize the testing across the ecosystem vendors, and accelerate the ability of enterprises to build or implement data-driven applications. In this presentation, Rakesh, as an expert in IBM BigInsights (IBM's Hadoop Distribution), will provide a brief overview of the major open source Hadoop tecnologies, how ODP integrates them, and how you can benefit in participatiing with, and adoption of, ODP. You will also learn how IBM incorporates ODP, and further expands on this platform with the addition of enterprise-rich features with BigInsigts 4.0.
name: The Move to Open Source Hadoop

description:
Come see the Phoenix-Local LiveStream of a major IBM | SPARK announcement from San Francisco!

Apache Spark is an open source processing engine built around speed, ease of use, and analytics. If you have large amounts of data that requires low latency processing that a typical Map Reduce program cannot provide, Spark is the alternative. Spark performs at speeds up to 100 times faster than Map Reduce for iterative algorithms or interactive data mining. Spark provides in-memory cluster computing for lightning fast speed and supports Java, Scala, and Python APIs for ease of development.


Spark allows data scientists to build models quickly and supports iterative jobs on distributed datasets. This means more people can apply deep intelligence into applications to make everything smarter, including the Internet of Things (IoT), machine learning, web, mobile, social, business process and more.


Do you believe in the value of Spark, in the speed, efficiency and flexibility of this in-memory compute engine? IBM does.  Emphatically.  That's why we're committed to do everything we can to accelerate the adoption of Spark for enterprise analytics, where Spark promises seemingly unlimited value. 


On June 15, 2015, IBM is hosting a Spark Community event in San Francisco, California: IBM | Spark - The Start of Something Big in Data and Design. There will be a Town Hall discussion featuring some of the most trail-blazing data scientists in today's Spark Community, including:


-  Edd Dumbill, VP Strategy, Silicon Valley Data Science
-  Mike Tamir, Chief Science Officer & VP of Data Science & Education at Galvanize
-   Fernando Perez, Staff Scientist at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory & Founding Investigator of the Berkeley Institute for Data Science
-   Haoyuan Li, CEO and Founder of Tachyon Nexus
-   Shankar Venkataraman, Distinguished Engineer & CTO, IBM Analytics Platform at IBM
-   Paco Nathan, Director, Community Evangelism, Databricks


Spark Community members will also deliver 5-minute lightning talks to describe exciting projects they're working on.

We will provide a livestream presentation of what these Spark leaders have to say.

Agenda:


6:15 pm - 7:00 pm - Networking & refreshments
7:00 pm - 8:15 pm  - LiveStream Announcements
8:15 pm - Q&A

Don't miss the opportunity to see this major announcement "live".
name: Apache Spark Announcement - Local LiveStream & Reception

description:
6:30 PM - Networking/Social
7:00 PM - Presentation Begins


Today's Web App Developers are looking for the quickest and most efficient ways to develop and deploy their code.  The advent of Cloud brings on a great opportunity to leverage services from every corner of the world -- but what is the most efficient way to take advantage of these services, and most quickly deploy your app?

IBM Master Inventor & Senior Software Engineer with the IBM CIO organization, Ryan DeJana, will provide a virtual lecture (live, moderated here in Phoenix) for our Meetup Group.  He will discuss how he and others have  sped their development and deployment (as well as added some great functionality) using the IBM BlueMix platform.


IBM Bluemix is an open-standards, cloud platform for building, running, and managing applications. With Bluemix, developers can focus on building excellent user experiences with flexible compute options, choice of DevOps tooling, and a powerful set of IBM and third-party APIs and services. 

Some of the Big Data offerings from Bluemix include Hadoop, DashDB, Geospatial, Analytics for Hadoop, Insights for Twitter and many more.

Attend to learn more not only to be more productive, but how to take advantage of a FREE demo account!
name: Cloud Foundry, Docker, or OpenStack - Why Choose?

description:
6:30-7:00PM - Networking & Pizza / Salads
7:00PM - Presentation Begins

Apache Spark™ is a fast and general engine for large-scale data processing.


Spark is a fast and general processing engine compatible with Hadoop data. It can run in Hadoop clusters through YARN or Spark's standalone mode, and it can process data in HDFS, HBase, Cassandra, Hive, and any Hadoop InputFormat. It is designed to perform both batch processing (similar to MapReduce) and new workloads like streaming, interactive queries, and machine learning.   see: http://spark.apache.org/faq.html


Rakesh brings his practical, enterprise experience back to present to our group a tour of Spark (TM) - covering everything from from basics, to API, then execution model and app dev, and finally extensions.

Please, if you RSVP, please attend or cancel your RSVP within 24 hours in advance of the meetup.  We will cater veggie or meat pizzas and a small selection of salads.

Hope to see you there.
name: Overview of Apache Spark - Presented by Rakesh Naik

description:
Node is just JavaScript they said. All you need is basic JS skills they said. They were right! And like it or not, it's making big headway in the web industry with large organizations integrating it, or shifting entirely.


In this talk we'll cover some of the nuances of Node.js development, starting with a discussion about what Node is at its core and some architecture and run-time basics. We'll also talk about scaling Node with a process manager and integrating metrics, monitoring, and profiling!

Developers of all levels will come out of this session with useful information and how to approach the 800-pound gorilla that is Node.js with no fear.


Speaker Bio:  Speaker Jordan Kasper

Shortly after it arrived at his home in 1993, Jordan began disassembling his first computer - his mother was not happy. She breathed more easily when he moved from hardware into programming. Jordan's experience includes companies large and small, universities, and numerous OSS projects. He also speaks at, and helps organize, local user groups, barcamps, hackathons, and conferences. Jordan's primary mission for the last 10 years has been to evangelize technology of all sorts and share what he has learned to help others grow. He currently works as a Developer Evangelist for StrongLoop, an IBM company and a leader in software solutions for Node.js. In his down time he enjoys puzzles of all sorts and board games!
name: Node.js: The 800-pound Gorilla in the Room

description:
Topic:
IT Operations Analytics (ITOA) is an approach or method applied to application software designed to retrieve, analyze and report data for IT operations. ITOA has been described as applying big data analytics to the IT realm [Wikipedia]. We will discuss Big Data analytic approaches embedded in log analysis and predictive insights as applied to operational management data such as events, configuration data and application and system logs.

Presenters:
Michael Kaczmarski, CTO, IT Service Management, IBM Systems Middleware, (kacz@us.ibm.com).

Mr. Kaczmarski is an IBM Fellow and Chief Technology Officer IT Service Management Products. He is currently driving efforts to integrate the cloud hosting services environment and user experience for service management capabilities delivered through software as a service (SaaS) in support of Hybrid cloud workloads. He leads cross product architecture efforts through customer relationships and development team strategy. Deeply involved in bringing Tivoli Storage Manager to market from its birth in IBM research, Michael worked on storage software products for over 14 years. His 32 year history with IBM has also included database design and development, scientific programming and IT management and support. He has Masters degree in Computer Science from National Technological University and a Bachelor’s Degree in Management Information Systems from the University of Arizona.

Omkar Nimbalkar is the Director of IT Operations Analytics & Visualization responsible for Engineering, Offering Management, and IT services. He has deep expertise in Big Data Search & Predictive Analytics, and breadth of experience across IBM’s Middleware portfolio. He has held leadership roles in Information Management, Rational, Tivoli, and Security divisions of IBM, both in the US and as a Lab Director in India. Omkar was also Technical Assistant to the CTO & VP of Strategy & Technology in IBM’s Software Group. Omkar is passionate about Corporate Social Responsibility, and championed IBM’s Smarter City – Pune program collaborating with municipal government for betterment of city health & transportation. - See more at: http://servicemanagement360.com/author/omkar-n/#sthash.CCD5j8S0.dpuf
name: IT Operations Analytics (ITOA) & Big Data Analytic Approaches

description:
Join us at this upcoming meetup were we will explore the topic that combines the interaction of software development and post-delivery operations – "DevOps".

Tim Barrios, former Development Manager with a large telecommunications firm in Arizona and currently DevOps Technical Specialist at IBM, will discuss how enterprises of all sizes provide continuous software delivery in order to seize market opportunities and reduce time-to-customer feedback. Additionally, Tim will discuss some of the best practices he has worked with in his own organizations and with IBM clients across the globe.

We will also delve into Agile development practices that have become common place in information technology and software development, including what agile development means, types of agile methods, and explore in greater detail the popular "Scrum" method.

You will leave the event armed with information on the best practices of modern development, continuous delivery, and the solutions needed to automate those practices.

About the Presenter: Tim Barrios

Since joining Rational in 1993, Tim Barrios has worked in several roles as a technical professional supporting Rational’s solutions. In his career with IBM Rational, Tim has supported most of the IBM Rational product line and has focused on Rational's design, construction, and process technologies. He has provided customers with professional services on software methods, agile processes, architecture, and Rational’s tools. Tim obtained his bachelor's and master's degrees in Computer Science from the University of Louisiana and Arizona State University, respectively.
name: "DevOps" - software development and post-delivery operations

description:
Redis is an open source (BSD licensed), in-memory data structure store, used as database, cache and message broker. It supports data structures such as strings, hashes, lists, sets, sorted sets with range queries, bitmaps, hyperloglogs and geospatial indexes with radius queries. Redis has built-in replication, Lua scripting, LRU eviction, transactions and different levels of on-disk persistence, and provides high availability via Redis Sentinel and automatic partitioning with Redis Cluster.
Redis Functions & Data Structures
When your apps need interactive data or your operational systems need a boost, there is no faster database than Redis. This is part of the reason Redis has become one of the fastest growing databases and the most popular database deployed in containers. In this talk, Dave Nielsen, Developer Advocate at Redis Labs, will share the functions and data structures used by Redis developers to solve common scalability challenges facing web scale companies. You can learn more about Redis at http://redislabs.com/ebook

About the Presenter: Dave Nielsen
Dave Nielsen works for Redis Labs; organizing hackathons, workshops and other events to help developers learn when and how to use Redis. Dave is also the co-founder and lead organizer of CloudCamp, a community of Cloud Computing enthusiasts in over 100 cities around the world. Dave graduated from Cal Poly: San Luis Obispo and has worked in developer relations for 12 years at companies like PayPal, Strikeiron and Platform D. Dave gained modest notoriety when he proposed to his girlfriend in the book "PayPal Hacks." You can follow Dave on twitter at http://twitter.com/davenielsen
name: Are you ready for Redis?

description:
On June 6, 2016, leading minds in data and analytics from Tesla, Netflix, Silicon Valley Data Science, and IBM will come together to demonstrate how open data and analytics technologies such as R, Spark, Python and more are forming a vibrant ecosystem.  The community has a shared goal of working with all data to build unexpected insights and launch new business applications.

The Apache Spark Maker Community Event will bring together data scientists, data engineers, data developers, and data designers June 6th @ 6pm at Galvanize, San Francisco. Here’s the plan:   

- The Big Reveal – New sample Apache Spark apps and tools

- Use Cases – Monsanto will share how they are using R and Spark to optimize their supply chain

- Learning Session - Hear from experts working on Spark projects and building the Spark ecosystem of open data and analytics technologies

- Networking Opportunity – Food, drinks and data, explore a Hall of Innovation showcasing Spark demos

Join us. Learn more here:  Apache Spark Maker Community Event 

Registration begins at 5:30 PM and the discussion starts at 6:30 PM; food and drinks will be served. You must register for this event. 

To get your ticket, and attend in person, click HERE. 

Can't attend in person? We'll be live streaming this event on a computer screen near you! Register for the  live stream and we'll send you a calendar update and login link.
name: Apache Spark Maker Community Event

description:
THIS IS A GLOBAL ON-LINE HACKATHON THAT BEGINS MAY 23, 2016 AND NOW ENDS AUGUST 23, 2016.  SUBMISSIONS DUE AUGUST 23rd BY 5:00 PM EST. 

We’re extending the hackathon deadline to August 23 - that’s 20 additional days to build your Spark enterprise app. (View the revised competition calendar HERE.  We're giving you more time because....

We’re adding new enterprise data resources to the site and we want to give you a chance to incorporate these into your projects, if you so choose.  Our awesome data co-sponsors Yelp and Uncharted Software have generously shared some of their enterprise data sets for you to use during the hackathon.

Yelp’s data includes 2.2M reviews by 552K users for 77K businesses. The Uncharted data includes Bitcoin network transactions from processing the Bitcoin blockchain as of mid-2014 and Amazon product reviews from 1995 through 2003. For a fuller description and data access, visit our resources page.

Uncharted Software also has a couple cool Spark data visualization libraries you should check out: Salt and SparkPipe.

And, in case you’d like to weigh the effects of weather on business operations, we’re also offering access to the full suite of Weather Company APIs for the duration of the hackathon.

Finally, if you’re looking for a hosting solution for your Spark app, we’re now offering extended Bluemix trials for all hackathon participants. Using Bluemix services to build your project is totally optional, but might be a good way to get your app up and running — particularly with the IBM Analytics for Apache Spark service.

You can request your extended Bluemix trial code here.  For all hackathon participants, trials will extend through November 1, 2016. Now go forth and optimize for the enterprise!

---------------------

Build an Apache Spark application to address a real business problem or core concern related to customer care, marketing, risk management or operations. Join IBM and Devpost for a global hackathon using Apache Spark Makers Build.  There are $100,000 in cash prizes.  Submissions can be sent in up to August 23rd.

Participation Details: To participate in the global virtual hackathon, you can register here.  Please review all registration guidelines.

For the hack, you will apply Apache Spark's powerful analytics capabilities to enterprise and other relevant data so data scientists and software developers can build an analytics or mobile/web app that tackles a key business problem in marketing, customer case, operations or risk management.  The grand prize is $50,000, and the top three winners each get a meeting with the judge or
Spark community expert of their choice; the judging panel includes data experts from Tesla, Netflix, and Silicon Valley Data Science.

Go to apachespark.devpost.com for full details and registration.  Please review all registration rules.

Questions?

We're here to help. If you have any questions about the hackathon, post on the discussion forum or email support@devpost.com and we'll respond as soon as we can.
name: Show Us Your Apps - Apache Spark Maker Build Global Hackathon

description:
RSVP: http://bit.ly/2gOcufe

This webinar will cover an overview of Watson Data Platform capabilities and how to empower users across the organization to make the most out of their data. What if you can shorten the time it takes to create value out of your existing organizational data ? 

What if you can provision a common analytic engine with managed services that will enable you to embrace multiple cloud platforms ? IBM Watson Data Platform is the first cloud-based data and analytics platform to support cognitive businesses. It enables access, collaboration and paths to insights by connecting all users through trusted access to a variety of data, discovering new possibilities and opportunities with built-in intelligence, automation and machine learning and accelerating outcomes with rapid deployment of new data models and fast embedding of insights into processes, applications and services. 

Let us show you how Watson Data Platform can be the milestone of your organization analytics strategy and empower your organization into the new Cognitive analytics era.

Speaker Bio:
Gerardo Rodríguez Díaz – is an avid traveler, technologist enthusiast and Big data and Analytics cloud solution specialist focused on communications and computer systems integrations industries across North America. GRD areas of specialization are IT, Marketing and Business Intelligence having worked across European, North and South American markets.
name: Making Data Simple in the Cognitive Era

description:
The demand for machine learning is booming! 

Calling all IT executives, data scientists, Chief Data Officers, data architects and other data geeks.  Join us on February 15th from 2:00-5:30 pm ET via livestream  (replay available starting February 16th) , and discover how machine learning is fundamentally changing the way we work and live.  Hear about cognitive applications that anticipate behavior and learn from data without being explicitly programmed.

You'll learn about the latest breakthrough developments on machine learning as well as Spark, data and analytics. Mike Gualtieri, Vice President and Principal Analyst, Forrester, will present his view on how to best leverage technologies such as big data, predictive analytics, Hadoop/Spark, machine learning, data science, and AI.  Rob Thomas, General Manager, IBM Analytics will host an agenda which will include guest speakers and cover the following topics:

•  Machine Learning Overview

•  Top Trends in Machine Learning & Cognitive Applications

•  Cognitive Analytics and Machine Learning for the Enterprise

•  Live Product Demonstration & Client Roundtable on Machine Learning

•  Data Innovation with Hybrid Transaction/Analytical Processing

•  Spark & Machine Learning for Enterprise Systems

For additional details and to REGISTER, please visit MACHINE LEARNING.

Register NOW and we'll send you a reminder!
how_to_find_us: Livestream is Eastern Standard Time (EST) - Adjust to your time zone
name: Machine Learning Launch
